questions.question: A building or structure shall be supplied by a maximum of how many services?

explanation.short: A building or structure shall be supplied by only one service unless permitted by exceptions.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.2 states that a building or structure shall be supplied by only one service unless conditions for additional services are met.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.2 for number of services permitted.

questions.question: The minimum clearance for service drop conductors over a residential driveway is:

explanation.short: Service drops over residential driveways require 12 feet minimum clearance.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.24(B)(1) requires 12 ft clearance over residential property and driveways.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.24(B) for service drop clearances.

questions.question: Service drop conductors over public streets or alleys require a minimum clearance of:

explanation.short: Service drops over public streets require 18 feet minimum clearance.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.24(B)(4) requires 18 ft clearance over public streets, alleys, roads, and parking areas subject to truck traffic.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.24(B)(4) for public road clearances.

questions.question: The minimum clearance for service drop conductors over a roof with a slope of 4 in 12 or greater is:

explanation.short: Roof clearance can be reduced to 3 feet for roofs with 4 in 12 or greater slope.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.24(A) Exception No. 2 permits 3 ft clearance where the roof has a slope of 4 in 12 or greater.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.24(A) Exception No. 2 for sloped roof clearances.

questions.question: The general rule for service drop clearance above a roof is:

explanation.short: Service drop conductors must maintain 8 feet clearance above a roof.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.24(A) requires a vertical clearance of not less than 8 ft above the roof surface.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.24(A) for roof clearance requirements.

questions.question: Service entrance conductors installed as open conductors without splice throughout their length are called:

explanation.short: Service entrance conductors from the service drop to the service equipment are overhead system conductors.
explanation.detailed: Article 100 defines service-entrance conductors, overhead system, as the conductors from the service drop to the service equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: See Article 100 definitions for service-entrance conductors.

questions.question: Underground service conductors between the utility transformer and the service equipment are called:

explanation.short: Service lateral is the underground service conductors from utility to service point.
explanation.detailed: Article 100 defines service lateral as the underground conductors between the utility and the service point.
explanation.how_to_find: See Article 100 definitions for service lateral.

questions.question: The maximum number of service disconnects permitted in a single enclosure or grouped is:

explanation.short: A maximum of six service disconnects are permitted grouped at one location.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.71(A) permits not more than six switches or sets of circuit breakers as the service disconnect.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.71(A) for maximum number of disconnects.

questions.question: Each service disconnect must be:

choices.text: Permanently marked to identify it as a service disconnect

explanation.short: Service disconnects must be permanently marked to identify them.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.70(B) requires each service disconnect to be permanently marked to identify it as a service disconnect.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.70(B) for service disconnect marking.

questions.question: The service disconnecting means must be installed at a:

explanation.short: Service disconnecting means must be readily accessible.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.70(A)(1) requires the service disconnect to be installed at a readily accessible location.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.70(A)(1) for service disconnect location.

questions.question: Service disconnecting means must disconnect:

choices.text: All conductors including the grounded conductor

explanation.short: Service disconnect must simultaneously disconnect all ungrounded service conductors.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.70(A) requires the service disconnecting means to disconnect all ungrounded conductors from the premises wiring.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.70(A) for service disconnect requirements.

questions.question: For a one-family dwelling, the minimum service disconnect rating is:

explanation.short: One-family dwellings require a minimum 100-ampere service disconnect.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.79(C) requires a minimum 100-ampere service for one-family dwellings.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.79(C) for dwelling service rating.

questions.question: The minimum rating for a service disconnect supplying any load is:

explanation.short: Service disconnects must be rated not less than 60 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.79(A) requires the service disconnecting means to have a rating of not less than 60 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.79(A) for minimum service disconnect rating.

questions.question: Service overcurrent protection shall be provided:

explanation.short: Overcurrent protection must be provided for each ungrounded service conductor.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.90(A) requires each ungrounded service conductor to have overload protection.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.90(A) for service overcurrent protection.

questions.question: Service entrance conductors shall be sized to carry:

choices.text: Not less than the calculated load

explanation.short: Service entrance conductors must have ampacity not less than the calculated load.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.42(A) requires service entrance conductors to have an ampacity not less than the calculated load per Article 220.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.42(A) for service conductor sizing.

questions.question: The minimum size service entrance conductors for a 100-ampere service is:

explanation.short: 100-ampere service requires minimum 4 AWG copper service entrance conductors.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.42(A)(2) and Table 310.16 require conductors with adequate ampacity for 100A.
explanation.how_to_find: Cross-reference 230.42 with Table 310.16 for conductor sizing.

questions.question: Service entrance cables shall be supported within how many inches of the weatherhead?

explanation.short: Service entrance cables must be supported within 12 inches of the service head.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.54(C) requires service entrance cables to be supported within 12 inches of the service head.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.54(C) for service cable support requirements.

questions.question: Service conductors from the service head shall extend:

explanation.short: Conductors shall be long enough to form drip loops below the service head.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.54(B) requires conductors to be of sufficient length to form drip loops.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.54(B) for drip loop requirements.

questions.question: The service head shall be located:

choices.text: At or above the service drop connection

explanation.short: Service head must be at or above the point of attachment of the service drop.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.54(A) requires the service head to be located above the point of attachment, or within 24 inches if not practical.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.54(A) for service head location.

questions.question: The point of attachment for service drop conductors shall not be less than:

explanation.short: Point of attachment must be at least 10 feet above finished grade.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.26 requires the point of attachment to be not less than 10 ft above finished grade.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.26 for point of attachment height.

questions.question: A service mast used for support of service drop conductors must be of adequate strength or be supported by:

choices.text: Guy wires or other approved means

explanation.short: Service masts must be adequate strength or supported by braces or guys.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.28 requires service masts to be of adequate strength or supported by braces, guys, or other approved means.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.28 for service mast support requirements.

questions.question: The service disconnect shall be installed at the:

choices.text: Nearest point of entrance or outside the building

explanation.short: Service disconnect must be at the nearest point of entrance or outside.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.70(A)(1) requires the service disconnect to be installed at a readily accessible location either outside or inside nearest the point of entrance.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.70(A)(1) for service disconnect location.

questions.question: Wiring methods permitted for service entrance conductors include:

choices.text: RMC, IMC, EMT, SE cable, and other approved methods

explanation.short: Multiple wiring methods including RMC, IMC, EMT, and SE cable are permitted.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.43 lists acceptable wiring methods for service entrance conductors.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.43 for permitted service entrance wiring methods.

questions.question: Service entrance conductors entering a building shall:

explanation.short: Service entrance conductors must be protected from physical damage.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.50 requires service entrance cables or individual conductors to be protected from physical damage.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.50 for service conductor protection.

questions.question: Underground service conductors shall have a minimum burial depth of:

explanation.short: Underground rigid metal conduit service conductors require 18 inches minimum cover.
explanation.detailed: Table 300.5 specifies minimum cover requirements; RMC requires 6 inches under buildings, 18 inches elsewhere.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 300.5 for burial depth requirements.

questions.question: When multiple disconnects are used as the service disconnecting means, they must be:

explanation.short: Multiple service disconnects must be grouped at one location.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.71(A) requires the service disconnects to be grouped.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.71(A) for grouping requirements.

questions.question: The grounded conductor of a service shall be:

choices.text: Run to each service disconnecting means
Connected to the equipment grounding conductor only

explanation.short: The grounded conductor must be run to each service disconnecting means.
explanation.detailed: Section 250.24(C) requires the grounded conductor to be routed to each service disconnecting means.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 250.24(C) for grounded conductor routing.

questions.question: Additional services are permitted for:

choices.text: Fire pumps, emergency systems, or when capacity requirements exceed 2000 amperes

explanation.short: Additional services are permitted for fire pumps, emergency systems, or large capacity needs.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.2(A) lists permitted conditions for additional services including fire pumps, emergency, and capacity over 2000A.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.2(A) for additional service conditions.

questions.question: Clearance of service drop conductors from windows that can be opened is:

explanation.short: Service drop conductors must be 3 feet from windows that can be opened.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.9 requires overhead service conductors to have 3 ft clearance from windows that can be opened.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.9 for clearances from building openings.

questions.question: Service conductors passing through a building shall be:

choices.text: Enclosed in a raceway or installed as service entrance cable

explanation.short: Service conductors through a building must be enclosed in raceway or cable.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.6 requires service conductors installed inside a building to be enclosed.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.6 for service conductor enclosure requirements.

questions.question: SE cable (Service Entrance cable) Type USE is rated for:

explanation.short: Type USE (Underground Service Entrance) cable is rated for underground installation.
explanation.detailed: Article 338 covers SE cable; Type USE is identified for underground use.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Article 338 for SE cable types and uses.

questions.question: The neutral conductor of a 3-wire, single-phase service shall not be smaller than:

choices.text: Always equal to the phase conductors

explanation.short: The neutral must be sized for the maximum unbalanced load.
explanation.detailed: Section 220.61 addresses neutral conductor sizing based on maximum unbalanced load.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 220.61 for neutral load calculations.

questions.question: Ground-fault protection of equipment is required for solidly grounded wye services of more than:

choices.text: 150 volts to ground and 800 amperes or more

explanation.short: GFPE is required for services more than 150V to ground and 800A or more (typically 480Y/277V).
explanation.detailed: Section 230.95 requires GFPE for solidly grounded wye services more than 150V to ground and 800A or more.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.95 for GFPE requirements.

questions.question: Service entrance cable shall be supported at intervals not exceeding:

explanation.short: Service entrance cables must be supported at intervals not exceeding 4.5 feet.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.51(A) requires SE cable to be supported at intervals not exceeding 4.5 ft (1.4 m).
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.51(A) for SE cable support intervals.

questions.question: Service equipment shall be listed and marked:

choices.text: Suitable for use as service equipment

explanation.short: Service equipment must be listed and marked suitable for use as service equipment.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.66 requires service equipment to be listed and marked as suitable for use as service equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.66 for service equipment listing requirements.

questions.question: Overcurrent devices shall be located:

explanation.short: Overcurrent devices must be readily accessible.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.24(A) requires overcurrent devices to be readily accessible.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.24(A) for overcurrent device location.

questions.question: Overcurrent devices shall not be located in the vicinity of:

choices.text: Easily ignitible material such as clothes closets

explanation.short: Overcurrent devices cannot be in the vicinity of easily ignitible materials.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.24(D) prohibits overcurrent devices in the vicinity of easily ignitible material, such as clothes closets.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.24(D) for prohibited locations.

questions.question: Overcurrent devices shall not be located in:

explanation.short: Overcurrent devices are not permitted in bathrooms.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.24(E) prohibits overcurrent devices in bathrooms.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.24(E) for bathroom prohibition.

questions.question: The standard ampere ratings for fuses and fixed-trip circuit breakers include:

explanation.short: Standard ratings include 15, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, etc.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.6(A) lists standard ampere ratings including 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50, 60, etc.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.6(A) for standard ampere ratings.

questions.question: A panelboard shall be protected by an overcurrent device having a rating not greater than:

explanation.short: Panelboard overcurrent protection cannot exceed the panelboard rating.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.36 requires panelboard overcurrent protection not exceeding the panelboard rating.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.36 for panelboard overcurrent protection.

questions.question: Panelboards shall be:

choices.text: Mounted in a dry location only
Durably marked by the manufacturer with voltage, amperage, and other ratings

explanation.short: Panelboards must be durably marked with ratings by the manufacturer.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.58 requires panelboards to be durably marked with voltage, amperage, number of phases, and manufacturer name.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.58 for panelboard marking requirements.

questions.question: The minimum headroom for working space around panelboards is:

explanation.short: Working space requires a minimum of 6 feet 6 inches headroom.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(A)(3) requires a minimum headroom of 6.5 ft (2.0 m) for working spaces.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(A)(3) for headroom requirements.

questions.question: For equipment rated 120V to ground, the minimum depth of working space (Condition 1) is:

explanation.short: Condition 1 working space depth is 3 feet for 0-150V systems.
explanation.detailed: Table 110.26(A)(1) requires 3 ft minimum working space depth for 0-150V, Condition 1.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 110.26(A)(1) for working space depth.

questions.question: The minimum width of working space in front of electrical equipment is:

choices.text: 30 inches or width of equipment, whichever is greater

explanation.short: Working space width is 30 inches or equipment width, whichever is greater.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(A)(2) requires working space width of 30 in. or width of equipment, whichever is greater.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(A)(2) for working space width.

questions.question: Working space about electrical equipment operating at 1000 volts or less shall not be used for:

explanation.short: Working space cannot be used for storage.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(B) prohibits the working space from being used for storage.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(B) for working space restrictions.

questions.question: Illumination is required for:

choices.text: Working spaces about service equipment, switchboards, panelboards, and motor control centers

explanation.short: Illumination is required for working spaces about service equipment, switchboards, panelboards, and MCCs.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(D) requires illumination for working spaces about service equipment, switchboards, panelboards, and MCCs indoors.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(D) for illumination requirements.

questions.question: For equipment rated over 1200 amperes, at least one entrance/egress to working space must be at least:

explanation.short: For over 1200A equipment, entrance must be 24 inches wide and 6.5 feet high minimum.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(C)(2) requires at least one entrance not less than 24 in. wide and 6.5 ft high for equipment over 1200A.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(C)(2) for entrance requirements.

questions.question: For switchboards and panelboards over 1200 amperes in a room with only one entrance, a second entrance/egress is required when:

choices.text: Working space depth exceeds twice the minimum required

explanation.short: Second entrance required when equipment is over 6 feet wide with only one entrance.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(C)(2) requires a second entrance/egress if equipment is over 6 ft wide.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(C)(2) for second entrance requirements.

questions.question: Circuit breakers used as switches in 120V and 277V fluorescent lighting circuits shall be:

choices.text: Listed and marked SWD or HID

explanation.short: Circuit breakers for fluorescent lighting must be marked SWD or HID.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.83(D) requires circuit breakers used as switches for fluorescent lighting to be listed and marked SWD or HID.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.83(D) for switching duty breakers.

questions.question: Panelboards in dwelling units supplying 15 and 20-ampere branch circuits shall be provided with:

explanation.short: Dwelling unit panelboards require AFCI protection for 15 and 20A branch circuits in specified areas.
explanation.detailed: Section 210.12(A) requires AFCI protection for dwelling unit branch circuits in bedrooms and other areas.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 210.12(A) for AFCI requirements.

questions.question: Each circuit breaker in a panelboard shall be:

choices.text: Legibly identified as to its purpose

explanation.short: Each circuit breaker must be legibly identified as to its purpose.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.4(A) requires every circuit and modification to be legibly identified as to its purpose.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.4(A) for circuit identification.

questions.question: Circuit directory information on panelboards shall be:

choices.text: Located on the exterior of the building

explanation.short: Circuit directory must be durable and accurate.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.4(A) requires circuit identification to be in a manner that is durable and accurate.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.4(A) for directory requirements.

questions.question: Panelboard cabinets and frames shall be:

explanation.short: Panelboard cabinets and frames must be grounded.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.60 requires panelboard cabinets and frames to be grounded.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.60 for panelboard grounding.

questions.question: A panelboard shall be installed in a cabinet or enclosure designed for:

explanation.short: Panelboard enclosures must be designed for the purpose and location.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.38 requires panelboards to be installed in enclosures designed for the purpose and location.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.38 for enclosure requirements.

questions.question: Meter socket enclosures shall not be used as:

choices.text: Junction boxes or raceways for conductors other than service conductors

explanation.short: Meter sockets cannot be used as junction boxes for non-service conductors.
explanation.detailed: Section 312.5 prohibits enclosures for service equipment from being used as junction boxes for conductors feeding through or tapping off.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 312.5 for enclosure use restrictions.

questions.question: Circuit breakers shall clearly indicate whether they are in the:

explanation.short: Circuit breakers must clearly indicate ON or OFF position.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.81 requires circuit breakers to clearly indicate whether they are in the ON or OFF position.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.81 for circuit breaker indication.

questions.question: Circuit breakers shall be:

choices.text: Manufactured by the panel manufacturer only
Trip free and capable of being closed and opened by manual operation

explanation.short: Circuit breakers must be trip free and capable of manual operation.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.80 requires circuit breakers to be trip free and capable of being closed and opened manually.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.80 for circuit breaker operation.

questions.question: A circuit breaker used to switch 120V fluorescent lighting must be rated at least:

explanation.short: Must be at least 15A and marked SWD for fluorescent lighting switching duty.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.83(D) requires at least 15A rating and SWD marking for fluorescent lighting circuits.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.83(D) for switching duty requirements.

questions.question: The rating of a circuit breaker or fuse that protects conductors must not exceed:

choices.text: The ampacity of the conductors it protects

explanation.short: Overcurrent protection cannot exceed conductor ampacity.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.4 requires conductors to be protected against overcurrent in accordance with their ampacities.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.4 for conductor protection.

questions.question: The next higher standard overcurrent device rating is permitted for conductors (small conductor rule) up to:

explanation.short: Next higher standard rating permitted for conductors up to 800A.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.4(B) permits the next higher standard overcurrent device rating for conductors where ampacity does not correspond to a standard rating, up to 800A.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.4(B) for the 800A rule.

questions.question: 14 AWG copper conductors shall be protected at not more than:

explanation.short: 14 AWG copper requires 15A maximum overcurrent protection.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.4(D)(3) limits 14 AWG copper conductor overcurrent protection to 15 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.4(D)(3) for small conductor protection.

questions.question: 12 AWG copper conductors shall be protected at not more than:

explanation.short: 12 AWG copper requires 20A maximum overcurrent protection.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.4(D)(5) limits 12 AWG copper conductor overcurrent protection to 20 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.4(D)(5) for small conductor protection.

questions.question: 10 AWG copper conductors shall be protected at not more than:

explanation.short: 10 AWG copper requires 30A maximum overcurrent protection.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.4(D)(7) limits 10 AWG copper conductor overcurrent protection to 30 amperes.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.4(D)(7) for small conductor protection.

questions.question: In a panelboard, the grounded conductor (neutral) terminations shall be:

choices.text: On the same bar as equipment grounds in all cases
Identified by the manufacturer for termination of grounded conductors
At the top of the panel only

explanation.short: Neutral terminations must be identified by the manufacturer for that purpose.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.41 requires terminals for grounded conductors to be identified.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.41 for neutral terminal identification.

questions.question: Service equipment rated at 1000 amperes or more shall have:

explanation.short: Service equipment 1000A or more must be field marked with available fault current.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.95(C) requires service equipment rated 1000A or more to be field marked with maximum available fault current.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.95(C) for fault current marking.

questions.question: Electrical equipment shall be installed in a manner that will:

choices.text: Allow ready access for examination, adjustment, and maintenance

explanation.short: Equipment must allow ready access for examination, adjustment, and maintenance.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26 requires equipment to be accessible for examination, adjustment, servicing, or maintenance.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26 for equipment accessibility.

questions.question: Electrical equipment shall be:

choices.text: Installed only if free from damage that would impair safe operation

explanation.short: Equipment must be free from damage that would impair safe operation.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.12 requires electrical equipment to be installed in a neat and workmanlike manner free from damage.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.12 for installation requirements.

questions.question: Unused openings in boxes and panelboards shall be:

explanation.short: Unused openings must be effectively closed.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.12(A) requires unused openings other than those intended for cable/raceway entry to be effectively closed.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.12(A) for closing unused openings.

questions.question: Equipment installed in wet locations shall be:

choices.text: Identified for use in wet locations

explanation.short: Equipment in wet locations must be identified for wet location use.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.28 requires equipment in wet locations to be identified for such locations.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.28 for wet location requirements.

questions.question: Conductors with different insulation temperature ratings terminated at equipment shall be:

choices.text: Used at the ampacity of the lowest rated conductor or equipment termination

explanation.short: Conductors must be used at the lowest rated conductor or termination temperature.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.14(C) requires ampacity to be based on the lowest temperature rating of any connected conductor or termination.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.14(C) for termination temperature ratings.

questions.question: Equipment terminals for conductors 14 AWG through 1 AWG shall be used at temperatures not exceeding:

explanation.short: Equipment terminals for smaller conductors are rated 60C unless marked otherwise.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.14(C)(1) requires terminations for 14-1 AWG conductors to be used at 60C unless marked for higher temperature.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.14(C)(1) for termination temperature limits.

questions.question: Equipment terminals for conductors larger than 1 AWG shall be used at temperatures not exceeding:

explanation.short: Larger conductor terminations are rated 75C unless marked otherwise.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.14(C)(1) requires terminations for conductors larger than 1 AWG to be used at 75C unless marked for higher temperature.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.14(C)(1) for termination temperature limits.

questions.question: Electrical connections shall be made:

choices.text: Using approved means such as pressure connectors, solder, or splicing devices

explanation.short: Connections must use approved means including pressure connectors, solder, or listed splicing devices.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.14(A) requires conductors to be connected using approved means.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.14(A) for connection requirements.

questions.question: Connection of conductors to terminal parts shall ensure:

choices.text: A good connection without damaging the conductors

explanation.short: Connections must be thorough without damaging conductors.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.14(A) requires connections to be made without damage to the conductors.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.14(A) for connection quality requirements.

questions.question: Unless identified for the purpose, different metals such as copper and aluminum shall not be:

choices.text: Intermixed within a terminal or splicing connector

explanation.short: Dissimilar metals cannot be intermixed in terminals unless identified for the purpose.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.14 prohibits mixing dissimilar metals in terminals unless the device is identified for the combination.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.14 for dissimilar metal requirements.

questions.question: A panelboard shall have a rating not less than:

explanation.short: Panelboard rating must be at least the minimum feeder capacity required.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.30 requires panelboards to have a rating not less than the minimum feeder capacity.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.30 for panelboard rating requirements.

questions.question: Switchboards and panelboards shall be:

explanation.short: Switchboards and panelboards must be dead-front type.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.38 requires panelboards to be of the dead-front type.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.38 for dead-front requirements.

questions.question: Fuses and circuit breakers shall have an interrupting rating:

choices.text: Sufficient for the voltage employed and current available at the line terminals

explanation.short: Interrupting rating must be sufficient for the voltage and available fault current.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.9 requires equipment intended to interrupt current to have adequate interrupting rating.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.9 for interrupting rating requirements.

questions.question: Equipment shall have a short-circuit current rating that:

choices.text: Permits the circuit protective device to clear the fault without damage

explanation.short: Equipment short-circuit rating must allow the protective device to clear faults without damage.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.10 requires equipment short-circuit current rating to permit the protective device to clear faults without extensive damage.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.10 for short-circuit current rating.

questions.question: The service point is the point of connection between:

choices.text: The utility facilities and the premises wiring
The service disconnect and the first branch circuit

explanation.short: Service point is where utility facilities connect to premises wiring.
explanation.detailed: Article 100 defines service point as the point of connection between utility facilities and premises wiring.
explanation.how_to_find: See Article 100 definitions for service point.

questions.question: Service equipment includes:

choices.text: Circuit breakers, switches, or fuses and their accessories at the service entrance

explanation.short: Service equipment includes overcurrent devices, switches, and accessories at service entrance.
explanation.detailed: Article 100 defines service equipment as the necessary equipment connected to the load end of service conductors.
explanation.how_to_find: See Article 100 definitions for service equipment.

questions.question: In subpanels (panels downstream of service equipment), the grounded conductor (neutral) and equipment grounding conductors shall be:

choices.text: Separated and isolated from each other
Connected to the same bar always

explanation.short: In subpanels, neutrals and equipment grounds must be separated.
explanation.detailed: Section 250.142 prohibits bonding the grounded conductor to equipment grounding conductors on the load side of service equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 250.142 for neutral-ground separation in subpanels.

questions.question: Service conductors supplying a building shall not pass through the interior of:

choices.text: Another building unless enclosed in specified methods

explanation.short: Service conductors cannot pass through another building unless properly enclosed.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.3 restricts service conductors from passing through the interior of another building without proper enclosure.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.3 for service conductor routing.

questions.question: Vegetation such as trees shall not be used for:

explanation.short: Trees and vegetation cannot be used to support overhead service conductors.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.10 prohibits vegetation such as trees from being used as support for overhead service conductors.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.10 for vegetation support prohibition.

questions.question: Service conductors shall have a minimum clearance from final grade over pedestrian areas only of:

explanation.short: Service conductors require 10 feet clearance over pedestrian-only areas.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.24(B)(2) requires 10 ft clearance above final grade for pedestrian areas not subject to vehicular traffic.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.24(B)(2) for pedestrian area clearances.

questions.question: Where practicable, service conductors shall be routed:

choices.text: Away from door and window openings

explanation.short: Service conductors should be routed away from doors and windows where practicable.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.9 requires service conductors to be routed away from openings where practicable.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.9 for routing around openings.

questions.question: Snap switches, circuit breakers, and fuseholders shall not be installed in:

explanation.short: Switches and breakers cannot be installed in faceup positions.
explanation.detailed: Section 404.6(C) prohibits snap switches from being installed in a faceup position.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 404.6(C) for switch position requirements.

questions.question: The maximum height to the center of the grip of the operating handle of a circuit breaker when in its highest position is:

explanation.short: Circuit breaker handles cannot be higher than 6 feet 7 inches to center of grip.
explanation.detailed: Section 240.24(A) limits the center of grip of breaker handles to not more than 6 ft 7 in. (2.0 m) above the floor.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 240.24(A) for mounting height limits.

questions.question: Service conductors installed as open conductors or cables shall be:

choices.text: Secured by straps or other approved means at intervals not exceeding specified distances

explanation.short: Service cables must be supported at specified intervals.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.51 requires service cables to be secured with straps or other approved means.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.51 for service cable support.

questions.question: The ground-fault protection system required for services shall be:

choices.text: Set to trip at any level

explanation.short: GFPE systems must be performance tested when first installed.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.95(C) requires ground-fault protection systems to be performance tested when first installed on site.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.95(C) for GFPE testing requirements.

questions.question: Ground-fault protection of equipment shall operate to cause the service disconnect to open at ground-fault currents of:

explanation.short: GFPE maximum setting is 1200 amperes.
explanation.detailed: Section 230.95(A) requires GFPE to operate at currents of 1200A or more.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 230.95(A) for GFPE setting requirements.

questions.question: For equipment rated 151V to 600V, the minimum depth of working space (Condition 2) is:

explanation.short: Condition 2 working space for 151-600V is 3.5 feet.
explanation.detailed: Table 110.26(A)(1) requires 3.5 ft (1.0 m) minimum working space depth for 151-600V, Condition 2.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 110.26(A)(1) for working space depths.

questions.question: For equipment rated 151V to 600V, the minimum depth of working space (Condition 3) is:

explanation.short: Condition 3 working space for 151-600V is 4 feet.
explanation.detailed: Table 110.26(A)(1) requires 4 ft (1.2 m) minimum working space depth for 151-600V, Condition 3.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to Table 110.26(A)(1) for working space depths.

questions.question: Condition 1 for working space exists when:

choices.text: Live parts are on one side and grounded parts on the other
Exposed live parts are on both sides
Exposed live parts are on one side and no live or grounded parts on the other

explanation.short: Condition 1 is exposed live parts on one side, no live or grounded parts opposite.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(A)(1) defines Condition 1 as exposed live parts on one side and no live or grounded parts on the other.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(A)(1) for working space conditions.

questions.question: Condition 2 for working space exists when:

choices.text: Exposed live parts are on one side and grounded parts on the other
Exposed live parts are on both sides

explanation.short: Condition 2 is exposed live parts on one side and grounded parts opposite.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(A)(1) defines Condition 2 as exposed live parts on one side and grounded parts on the other.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(A)(1) for working space conditions.

questions.question: Condition 3 for working space exists when:

choices.text: Exposed live parts are on one side only
Exposed live parts are on both sides of the working space

explanation.short: Condition 3 is exposed live parts on both sides of the working space.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.26(A)(1) defines Condition 3 as exposed live parts on both sides.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.26(A)(1) for working space conditions.

questions.question: Panelboards in damp or wet locations shall be:

choices.text: Installed to prevent moisture from entering

explanation.short: Panelboards in damp/wet locations must prevent moisture entry.
explanation.detailed: Section 408.37 requires panelboards in damp or wet locations to be installed to prevent moisture entry.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 408.37 for damp/wet location requirements.

questions.question: The NEC applies to:

choices.text: Installations of conductors and equipment within or on public and private buildings

explanation.short: The NEC covers installations within or on public and private buildings.
explanation.detailed: Section 90.2(A) defines the scope of the NEC including public and private premises.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 90.2(A) for NEC scope.

questions.question: Listed or labeled equipment shall be installed and used:

choices.text: In accordance with any instructions included in the listing or labeling

explanation.short: Listed equipment must be installed per listing/labeling instructions.
explanation.detailed: Section 110.3(B) requires listed equipment to be installed and used in accordance with listing instructions.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 110.3(B) for listed equipment installation.

questions.question: A main bonding jumper shall be installed at:

choices.text: Service equipment to connect the grounded conductor to the equipment grounding conductor

explanation.short: Main bonding jumper connects grounded conductor to equipment grounding at service.
explanation.detailed: Section 250.24(B) requires a main bonding jumper at service equipment to bond the grounded conductor to the equipment grounding conductor.
explanation.how_to_find: Go to 250.24(B) for main bonding jumper requirements.
